posts.name: Ainesh Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
This year, due to various reasons, for the first time, I’ve been at the FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC). There was significant variation in how teams approached auto alignment this year. I’ve seen everything from fully automated systems to not auto-aligning at all.

So I was curious if your team’s approach differs from what’s typically seen. Our method involved the driver controller vibrating when the driver was ready to place coral.

link_counts.title: How do you line up on the reef?

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: When I first read it I thought it was about something special but it turned out we didn’t do anything particularly unique. However I noticed a cool solution involving pink team 233. They used a camera pointed at the poles and a monitor with tape marking the alignment points. If the reef pole fell between those tape marks they knew it was aligned.

posts.name: Ryan Shavell
posts.cooked:
Our auto-align system manages alignment and scoring once activated. The driver selects between the left or right branch of the closest reef face using a designated button, followed by another button to specify L1 through L4. Upon activation, the robot navigates to the correct scoring position using PID control, adjusting the arm and elevator to setpoints before releasing the coral once mechanisms stabilize. Completion is signaled by a rumble command, allowing the driver to initiate the next cycle.

This system employs automation techniques such as Trigger composition, detailed in our RobotContainer file here [link]. The process involves:
- Driving to the target reef
- Configuring mechanism PIDs based on proximity to the targeted reef
- Initiating a score command when conditions are met

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: Here are some related discussions on the topic, including helpful links to previous threads on auto alignment and software strategies.

link_counts.title: Let’s Review REEFSCAPE’s Controls Software Strategy: How did you solve position and accuracy with software?
From zero to auto align to reef tutorial how to simply auto align to the reef
Teams, how do you tune Auto-Align and Vision to competition fields (Particularly for Reef Alignment)?

posts.cooked:
We put everything together in one command that performs a PID loop on the error between the Limelight MegaTag2 estimated position and the desired pose. It doesn’t utilize the SwerveDrivePoseEstimator odometry. This approach works effectively on its own, though we slightly enhanced its convergence behavior with this solution.  

The desired pose is calculated using trigonometry based on the reef angle. Both cameras are positioned exactly 6.5 inches from the center, ensuring that a Limelight unit always views the tag.  

Other features include automatic elevator adjustment and coral ejection based on distance/error calculations relative to the desired position.

link_counts.title: What cool things did you do in Software this year?

posts.name: Jack Ross
posts.cooked: We decided on a relative approach to align the April tags for the reef using Swerve in our first year. We utilized three PID systems to determine the X, Y, and Yaw positions of the April tags through PhotonVision. This data was then input into a drive command to navigate the robot towards the tags. Initially, we faced some challenges due to the camera being positioned too low and near the bumper, but overall, we had several productive days with the system.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: We conducted extensive iterations on camera placement this season. A key takeaway applicable to most, if not all, future games is that camera positioning should be an early factor in the robot architecture design.
